content: The Act may be cited as the "American Patriots of WWII through Service with the Canadian and British Armed Forces Gold Medal Act of 2017". Key findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that during World War Two, Americans volunteered for service with Canadian and British militaries to fight Nazi and Fascist aggression, perceiving the importance of the war and its impact on American life. Patriots independently crossed the border into Canada or sought out recruiting offices in major US cities. During WWII, Americans volunteered for Canadian and British armed forces, with many joining the Royal Canadian Air Force. Air Marshal William Avery Bishop recognized their contribution in a 1942 film. During World War Two, American volunteers who served in the Canadian and British armed forces will be awarded a single gold medal by Congress in recognition of their dedicated service. The Secretary of the Treasury will determine the design of the medal, and it will be displayed at the Smithsonian Institution after the award ceremony. The gold medal awarded to American volunteers who served in the Canadian and British armed forces during World War Two will be displayed at the Smithsonian Institution for research and may also be displayed elsewhere. The Secretary may create and sell bronze duplicates of the medal to cover production costs. SEC. 4. STATUS OF MEDALS. Medals struck under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code. All medals struck under this Act shall be considered numismatic items for purposes of section 5134 of title 31, United States Code.
